sp.p: And it is a very hard matter for a Man to be put upon proving every Diſcourſe that he has had about the publick Affairs of the time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: The Reaſon of your Exception is, that he has declared his opinion before hand, that the Party would be hanged or would ſuffer, that's a Reproach and a Reflection upon a Wiſe man ſo to do; and if they can prove it upon him let them do it: but whether you ſhould ask him ſuch a Queſtion, Whether he be a Fool or a Knave for the giving an opinion one way or other, that's the Queſtion before us.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Darnall.
sp.p: My Lord, we do not offer it to the Court as an Objection that he is not a Wiſe man.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: But what a Man does utter imprudently may occaſion a Prejudice againſt him, and therefore ought to be proved, and not he to prove it himſelf.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: Eſpecially being a Freeholder of London, and taking notice of what is done in London; and if he does take notice of the Fact, and does previouſly give his Opinion of a matter which he may be called upon a Jury to try, this is an Indiſcretion and a Reproach to him, and I think a Miſdemeanour.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Darnall.
sp.p: My Lord, I acknowledge it is ill done of him, that is, indiſcreetly and not wiſely, and we would have Diſcreet and Wiſe men upon our Jury.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cowper.
sp.p: My Lord, Mr. Serj. Darnall will make it ſo little a thing at laſt that it will amount to no cauſe of Challenge, if it were even proved againſt him, which we inſiſt it ought to be, it being their Objection, and the Party not being bound to prove it againſt himſelf; but truly we think there is more in it than ſo, becauſe it is an unjuſt prejudging of a Man before he is tryed and heard, and if ſo, it is a thing that he ought not to accuſe himſelf of, and therefore we oppoſe the asking any ſuch Queſtion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Darnall.
sp.p: Our Objection is not becauſe it is an Offence to declare a Man's opinion upon a Fact reported, but becauſe it ſhews he has a ſettled opinion againſt the Perſon of his Guilt, and ſo he is not ſo equal a Man to try him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: And is that like a Honeſt man and a Freeholder of London, (who ought to be indifferent) to come with a ſettled opinion againſt a Man, when he is to be one of his Jury?

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Darnall.
sp.p: Well, my Lord, we have been heard, and ſubmit it to the Judgment of the Court.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p:
Truly I think it reflects both Diſhoneſty and Diſhonour upon him, and therefore theſe Queſtions ought not to be askt. The Queſtion is not whether a Man (if ever ſuch a Man there were) that hath ſo reſolved and declared ſhall be ſworn? No; he is not fit to ſerve upon a Jury. But the Queſtion is, How this ſhall be diſcovered, by his own Oath or by other Proof? I think it ought to be made appear by other Proof, if true. A
Man attainted of Felony, Forgery, Falſe Verdict, or Perjury, ought not to ſerve on a Jury, yet he ſhall not be examined concerning the ſame on a Voire dire. And if there be in Court a Copy of ſuch Judgment carefully examined and kept by himſelf, he ſhall not be forced to Anſwer whether it be a true Copy; tho his Anſwer could not ſubject him to any further Penalty.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Darnall.
sp.p: My Lord, I hope no Gentleman of the Jury has done it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: I hope no Freeholder of London is ſo indiſcreet or ſo unjuſt. But if any Man in this Pannel have any particular Diſpleaſure to the Priſoner, or be unindifferent, or have declared himſelf ſo, I do admoniſh and deſire him to diſcover ſo much in general; for, it is not fit, nor for the honour of the King's Juſtice, that ſuch a Man ſhould ſerve on the Jury.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Darnall.
sp.p: We hope ſo too. We hope that all that are returned upon the Jury are diſcreet and impartial Men.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Well, Sir, what ſay you to this Gentleman Mr. Walker?

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: I challenge you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Nathanael Long.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: My Lord, we think he may ask if they have a Freehold or no; becauſe the Law requires that Qualification, and the Priſoner not being able to prove the Nagative, it puts the Proof of the Affirmative upon the Perſon himſelf.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What does Sir Bartholomew mean? would he have the Jury-men bring their Evidences with them to prove their Free-hold?

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: No ſure, Mr. Attorney; but to ask the Queſtion was allowed him the laſt time, and we will not deny him the ſame juſt Favour now.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Are you a Free-holder, Sir, in London of the value of 10 l. a year?

sp.speaker: Mr. Long.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Were you of the Grand-Jury when the Bill was found againſt me?

sp.speaker: Mr. Long.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: I challenge you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: William Carbonell.

sp.speaker: Mr. Carbonell.
sp.p: My Lord, I am no Free-holder.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: What, does he ſay he has no Free-hold?

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: Then he muſt be ſet aſide.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Joſhua Foster.

sp.speaker: Mr. Foſter.
sp.p: My Lord, I am no freeholder in London neither.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, we deſire they may be ſworn whether they have a Free-hold or not.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Hold Mr. Carbonell and Mr. Foſter the Book. (which was done ſeverally.) You ſhall true anſwer make to all ſuch Queſtions as ſhall be askt you by the Court. So help you God.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Ask him if he hath not a Freehold in London?

sp.speaker: Mr. Carbonell.
sp.p: No, I have not.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Have you or any body in truſt for you a Freehold in London of the Value of 10 l. a year?

sp.speaker: Mr. Carbonell.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Ar.
sp.p: Joſhua Foſter, have you or any in truſt for you any Eſtate of Free-hold in London of the Value of 10 l. a year?

sp.speaker: Mr. Foſter.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Joſeph Billers.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: I deſire they may be called in the order as they are in the Pannel, you have not called John Ewen, who is next.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: I do call them in order: as for Mr. Ewen, one has made Oath that he is ſick, and is not able to come hither. What ſay you to Mr. Billers? there he ſtands.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Sir, are you a Free-holder of 10 l. a year, within the City of London?

sp.speaker: Mr. Billers.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Was you of the Grand-Jury, Sir, when the Bill was found againſt me?

sp.speaker: Mr. Billers.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: I challenge you.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: John Child.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Sir, are you a Free-holder within the City of London?

sp.speaker: Mr. Child.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Of 10 l. a year?

sp.speaker: Mr. Child.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Were you of the Grand-Jury, when the Bill was found againſt me?

sp.speaker: Mr. Child.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: I challenge you.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Edward Leeds.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Sir, are you a Freeholder within the City of London, of 10 l. a year?

sp.speaker: Mr. Leeds.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Were you of the Grand-Jury that found the Bill againſt me?

sp.speaker: Mr. Leeds.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: I challenge you.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: What Queſtion was that he ask'd him?

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Whether he were one of the Grand-Jury that found the Bill.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: A very proper Queſtion: for an Indicter ought not to be a Tryer.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Thomas Clark.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Sir, are you a Free-holder within the City of London of 10 l. a year?

sp.speaker: Mr. Clark.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Were you of the Grand-Jury that found the Bill againſt me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Clark.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: I challenge you.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Nathan Green.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Are you a Free-holder, Sir, within the City of London, of the value of 10 l. a year.

sp.speaker: Mr. Green.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cook
sp.p: Were you of the GrandJury that found the Bill againſt me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Green.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: I challenge you.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Henry Sherbroke.

sp.speaker: Cook
sp.p: I have nothing to ſay againſt him.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Then hold Mr. Sherbroke the Book.

Look upon the Priſoner. You ſhall well and truly try, and true Deliverance make between our Sovereign Lord the King and the Priſoner at the Bar (whom you ſhall have in charge) according to your Evidence. So help you God.

div.p: (Then Mr. Sherbrooke was put into the Place appointed for the Jury.)

sp.speaker: Cook.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Were you of the Grand Jury that found the Bill againſt me?

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Sir, Are you a Freeholder of the City of London, of Ten pound a Year?

sp.speaker: Mr. Wyerſden.

sp.speaker: Cook.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.

sp.speaker: Mr. Burleigh.
sp.p: Write, write.

sp.speaker: Cook.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: William Smith.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Sir, Are you a Freeholder of the City of London, of Ten pound a Year?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Were you of the Grand Jury that found the Bill againſt me?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.

sp.speaker: Cook.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: John Bickly.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bickly.
sp.p: My Lord, I don't look upon my ſelf as a Freeholder?

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: Why ſo, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bickly.
sp.p: I have a Leaſe for One and fifty Years, my Lord, of my Houſe, and there is a very little piece of Ground adjoining to it that was very convenient for me to lay to my Leaſe; there is no way to it but through my Houſe; it is a thing that never was let for any thing, and it is not worth the Building.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: What Eſtate have you in it? Do you pay a Ground-Rent for it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bickly.
sp.p: My Lord, I bought that little piece of Ground for the Conveniency of my Leaſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: But did you purchaſe it for Term of Years, or to you and your Heirs?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bickly.
sp.p: Nay, I bought it for ever, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: Then you have a Freehold in it. What's the Value of it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bickly.
sp.p: Truly very little, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: I don't know any Body can judge of the Value of it but your ſelf. Is it worth Ten Pound a Year?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bickly.
sp.p: My Lord, I can't Value it at Ten Pound a Year, it never coſt me Forty Pound.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: Then for Eſtate you are well enough, but for Value you are a little under.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Thomas Collins.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: I accept of him.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: John Watſon.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: I do not Challenge him.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Benjamin Hooper.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: I accept of him.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: John Wells.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Sir, Are you a Freeholder of the City of London, of Ten pound a year?

sp.speaker: Mr. Wells.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Were you of the Grand Jury that found the Bill againſt me?

sp.speaker: Mr. Wells.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: I challenge you.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: John Hibbart.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Sir, Are you a Freeholder of the City of London, of Ten pound a year?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hibbart.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Were you of the Grand Jury that found the Bill againſt me?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hibbart.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: I challenge you.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Mr. Cook you have challenged your full Number. Call Daniel Wray.
(He was ſworn.)

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: John Pettit.

sp.speaker: Cryer
sp.p: Countez.
Henry Sherbrook.

sp.speaker: Cryer.
sp.p: One, &c.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: John Pettit.

sp.speaker: Cryer.
sp.p: Twelve good Men and true, ſtand together and hear your Evidence.

list.head: The Names of the Twelve ſworn are as follow:

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Cryer, Make Proclamation.

sp.speaker: Cryer.
sp.p: O Yez, If any one can inform my Lord, the King's Juſtices, the King's Serjeant, the King's Attorney-General, or this Inqueſt now to be taken of the High Treaſon whereof Peter Cook the Priſoner at the Bar ſtands Indicted, let them come forth and they ſhall be heard, for the now Priſoner ſtands at the Bar upon his Deliverance; and all others that are bound by Recognizance to give Evidence againſt the Priſoner at the Bar, let them come forth, and give their Evidence, or they forfeit their Recognizance.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: You muſt make room for thoſe Twelve Gentlemen that are ſworn, that they may be at eaſe; and for thoſe that are not ſworn, their Attendance may be ſpared.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Peter Cook, hold up thy Hand.

Upon this Indictment he has been Arraigned, and thereunto has pleaded Not Guilty, and for his Tryal hath put himſelf upon God and his Country, which Country you are, your Charge is to inquire whether he be guilty of the High-Treaſon whereof he ſtands Indicted, or not guilty; if you find him guilty, you are to inquire what Goods or Chattels, Lands or Tenements, he had at the time of the High-Treaſon committed, or at any time ſince; if you find him not guilty, you are to inquire whether he fled for it; if you find that he fled for it, you are to inquire of his Goods and Chattels as if you had ſound him Guilty; if you find him not Guilty, nor that he did fly for it, you are to ſay ſo, and no more, and hear your Evidence.

sp.speaker: Mr. Mompeſſon.
sp.p:
May it pleaſe your Lordſhip, and you Gentlemen that are ſworn, this is an Indictment for High Treaſon againſt Peter Cook, the Priſoner at the Bar, and the Indictment ſets forth, That whereas there has been an open and cruel War for a long time, and ſtill is between his Majeſty King William, and the French King, the Priſoner at the Bar not weighing the Duty of his Allegiance, the Firſt of July in the Seventh year of the King's Reign, Did Compaſs and Intend to Depoſe and Deprive the King of the Title, Honour, and Dignity of the Imperial Crown of this Realm, and likewiſe to put the King to Death, and did adhere to the King's Enemies; and to fulfil theſe Treaſons, he did Conſult with Chernock, and ſeveral other Traytors who were mentioned, there, and ſome of whom have been found Guilty of Treaſon, and executed for it, to ſend over to the late King James, to perſwade the French King to ſend over Soldiers and Arms to invade this Kingdom, and to raiſe an Inſurrection and Rebellion in it, and to Deprive and put the King to Death, and to compleat theſe Treaſons, it further ſets forth, That the Priſoner at the Bar did provide ſeveral Arms and Horſes, and this is
laid to be againſt the Duty of his Allegiance, againſt the King's Peace, Crown and Dignity, and againſt the Form of the Statute in that Caſe made and provided; to this he had pleaded Not Guilty, and for Tryal put himſelf upon the Country, and, Gentlemen, if we prove theſe Facts laid in the indictment, its your Duty to find him Guilty.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: May it pleaſe your Lordſhip, and you, Gentlemen of the Jury, the Priſoner at the Bar ſtands Indicted for High Treaſon.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: My Lord Chief-Juſtice, if your Lordſhip pleaſes, before the Witneſſes are Examined againſt me. I intreat you that they may not be both in Court together, that one may not hear what the other ſwears, tho' I ſuppoſe it is the ſame thing; for they have been together both now and the laſt day.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: Mr. Cook, I muſt tell you it is not neceſſary to be granted for asking; for we are not to diſcourage, or caſt any Suſpicion upon, the Witneſſes, when there is nothing made out againſt them; but it is a Favour that the Court may grant, and does grant ſometimes, and now does it to you; tho' it be not of neceſſity: they ſhall be examined apart, but at preſent this is not the time of Examination; for the King's Counſel are now to open the Evidence before they examine the Witneſſes; but when the time comes for the Witneſſes to be called and examined, the Court will, in favour to you, take care that your Requeſt be complied with.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: May it pleaſe your Lordſhip, the Priſoner ſtands Indicted for High Treaſon, in Compaſſing and Imagining the Death and Deſtruction of his Majeſty, and likewiſe in adhering to his Majeſty's Enemies, theſe are the Treaſons ſpecified in the Indictment: the Overt Acts that are laid to prove theſe Treaſons are, That he with ſeveral other Traitors, named in the Indictment, did Meet and Conſult, and agree to ſend over Chernock into France, to invite the French King to make an Invaſion upon the Kingdom, and did provide Arms for that purpoſe.

Gentlemen, the nature of the Evidence that you will have produced to prove the Priſoner Guilty of theſe Treaſons lies thus: It will appear to you that there has been for ſome time a Conſpiracy carried on by ſeveral Traytors, and Wicked Perſons, to ſubvert the eſtabliſhed Government of this Kingdom, and deſtroy the Conſtitution of England, by a Foreign Invaſion of the French. You will hear that this Conſpiracy was laid wide, and conſiſted of ſeveral parts, one part was that of Aſſaſſinating his Majeſty's Royal Perſon, and that was to be done firſt, as a Preparation and Encouragement to the French to invade the Kingdom: the other part was the inviting the French King to invade us, and the Priſoner at the Bar is accuſed of being concerned in that part that relates to the Invaſion of this Kingdom, by a French Power; and tho' it may be the other part, that of Aſſaſſinating the King, be the Blackeſt part of the Conſpiracy, yet if the Priſoner at the Bar has been ingaged in the inviting a Foreign Power to invade the Kingdom, my Lords, the Judges, will tell you, in Point of Law, that is as much an Overt Act of the Compaſſing the Deſtruction of the King and People of England, and the Subverſion of our ancient good Conſtitution, as if he had been concerned immediately in the other part, the Aſſaſſination.

But now, Gentlemen, that the Priſoner was ingaged in Inviting the French to Invade us, you will hear proved by ſeveral Witneſſes, that there having been a Deſign laſt Year, juſt before his Majeſty went to Flanders, to expoſe his own Perſon for our Protection, and the Protection of the Liberties of Europe, there was a Conſpiracy to Murder him before he went to Flanders, which, it ſeems, they were not ripe for then; but immediately after he was gone to Flanders, you will hear there were formal Meetings of ſeveral Gentlemen and Perſons of Quality, among whom the Priſoner at the Barr was one: There was a Meeting in May, laſt Year, after the King was gone to Flanders; and this was at the Old King's Head in Leaden-Hall-ſtreet; and there were preſent, my Lord of Aylesbury, my Lord Montgomery, Sir William Parkyns, Sir John Freind, Mr. Chernock, (all which Three laſt have ſuffered the Puniſhment of-the Law for their Treaſon already;) and there were alſo Mr. Cook, the Priſoner at the Barr, Mr. Porter and Mr. Goodman; theſe Men did meet together' to conſider of the beſt Ways and Means of Encouraging and Inviting the French King with an Armed Force to Invade this Kingdom; They conſidered that That was a proper Opportunity, and did treat of ſeveral Arguments that might perſwade to it: Firſt, that the King was gone to Flanders, and ſo was not in Perſon here to Defend us; and that the Troops, to make good ſuch Defence, were in a great meaſure drawn thither, to aſſiſt the Allies againſt the French Power; They did think likewiſe, that at that time there was a great Diſcontent and Diſſatisfaction in the Nation, though I think in that they were greatly miſtaken; and I believe and hope they will always find themſelves ſo, to think that the People of England are ſo little ſenſible of that which is the means of their Preſervation, as to hearken to any Diſcontents to Incourage a French Power to come into England to deſtroy our Religion and Liberties; that indeed they did apprehend, though they were miſtaken, and I believe they always will, when they go upon that ground.

Gentlemen, Theſe Perſons thinking this a proper Opportunity, did agree to ſend a Meſſenger into France upon this Meſſage, To go to the late King James, and perſwade him to deſire and prevail with the French King to aſſiſt him with Ten thouſand Men, 8000 Foot, 1000 Horſe, and 1000 Dragoons; and to incourage him, they promiſed their Aſſiſtance here, as ſoon as he came over; and undertook, that between them, they could furniſh, and wou'd raiſe 2000 Horſe to meet him at his Landing, and joyn upon ſuch an Invaſion.

Gentlemen, At this Meeting this was agreed upon by all that were there, whereof the Priſoner was one; and they did agree to ſend Mr. Chernock, (who has ſince been executed, and a principal Incourager of the Deſign, and Actor in it;) he was the Meſſenger that was appointed to go upon this Errand, and Mr. Chernock was reſolved to go, but deſired another Meeting of theſe Gentlemen, to know if they continued in their former Reſolution, that he might have all the Aſſurance that was Reaſonable to give the French King Incouragement to make the Invaſion: Accordingly another Meeting was had of moſt of the ſame perſons that were at the Meeting before; particularly the Priſoner at the Barr was at that ſecond Meeting, which was in Covent-Garden at one Mrs. Mountjoy's, who keeps a Tavern next door to Sir John Fenwick's Lodgings; there they met upon the ſame Deſign, and upon Conſultation had, and the Queſtion ask'd, they did agree to continue in the former Reſolution, and upon that immediately Mr. Chernock went into France to ſollicit Forces from thence to Invade us; but it happ'ned, as it ſeems, that the French King's Forces were otherwiſe imployed, ſo that he cou'd not ſpare ſo many at that time; and this Return was brought by Chernock to the Gentlemen that imployed him; That he had ſpoke with the late King, who gave him that Anſwer,
That the French King cou'd not ſpare ſo many Men at that time, but he thank'd them for their Kindneſs.

Gentlemen, This will be the nature of Our Evidence, to ſhow, that the Priſoner at the Barr was concerned in that part of the Conſpiracy which relates to the French Invaſion; and if he be guilty of that, in point of Law, he is as much guilty of the Conſpiracy, to Depoſe and Murder the King, as if he had been concerned in the other part of Aſſaſſinating his Royal Perſon; and I believe no body can think that thoſe that were to act in the Aſſaſſination, wou'd have attempted to ingage in ſuch a deſperate Deſign, if it had not been for the Incouragement of the French Invaſion that was to ſecond them afterwards, if they ſucceeded; ſo that no body can extenuate the Crime of the Invaſion, becauſe as to the Horridneſs of the Attempt, it is leſs Black than the other; they are both Crimes of a very high nature, and equally High-Treaſon; and if we prove the Priſoner Guilty of this part, we hope you will find him Guilty.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, we will call our Witneſſes and prove the Matter, as it has been opened. Call Captain Porter and Mr. Goodman.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Darnall.
sp.p: Now, my Lord, we muſt deſire that That may be done which our Client deſired before, and which your Lordſhip was favourably pleaſed to promiſe, that the Witneſſes may be examined a-part.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: Let it be ſo: Who do you begin with?

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: We begin with Captain Porter, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J Treby.
sp.p: Then let Mr. Goodman withdraw.

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: Let Mr. Goodman go up Stairs, and we will call him preſently.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Swear Captain Porter: (which was done.) Captain Porter, Do you know Mr. Cook, the Priſoner at the Barr?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Do you remember a Meeting of ſome Gentlemen at the King's-Head Tavern in Leaden Hall-ſtreet?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: Yes, I do, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Then pray give an Account of the Company that were there, the Time when, and what paſsd.

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: My Lord, the laſt Year we had two Meetings; the Firſt was in May, the other was the latter end of May, or the beginning of June; the Firſt was at the Kings-Head in Leaden-Hall-ſtreet; there were my Lord of Aylesbury, my Lord Montgomery, Sir John Fenwick, Sir John Freind, Sir William Parkyns, Mr. Chernock, Mr. Cook and my ſelf; Mr. Goodman came in after Dinner; at this Meeting it was Conſulted which was the beſt way and the quickeſt to Reſtore King James, and haſten his Return into England; ſeveral Diſcourſes and Propoſals there were; at laſt it was agreed to ſend Mr. Chernock to the late King to borrow of the French King Ten thouſand Men, 8000 Foot, 1000 Horſe, and 1000 Dragoons, to be ſent over into England to aſſiſt the King's Reſtoration. Says Mr. Chernock thereupon, This the King can do without your ſending, and I wou'd not go upon a fooliſh Errand. What will you do to Aſſiſt in this Matter? the Company deſir'd him to promiſe King James, That if he wou'd ſend word when he Landed, and where, they wou'd be ſure to meet him at his Landing with a Body of 2000 Horſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Was the Priſoner at the Barr in the Company, and preſent at this Reſolution?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: Yes, he was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did all the Company agree to it?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: Yes, they did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What ſigns were there of their Agreement? did they ſtand up ſeverally and declare their Agreement, or how?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: My Lord of Aylesbury and Sir John Fenwick did riſe up, and deſired Captain Chernock, that he wou'd go upon this Errand: And when the Queſtion was ask'd ſeverally of all there preſent by Mr. Chernock, Whether he might aſſure the King of what they had told him? Every one ſaid Yes, you may; and Mr. Cook kneel'd indeed upon a Chair, and ſaid Yes, you may.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did he give his Conſent to it?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: Yes, he anſwer'd in thoſe very words.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Do you remember any Meeting of any Company at Mrs. Mountjoy's?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: Yes, that was a ſecond Meeting.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Pray tell my Lord and the Jury, how you came to meet there then, what Company were there, and what paſs'd.

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: Mr. Chernock deſir'd another Meeting, to ſee if the Gentlemen kept to their former Reſolution; and we met at Mrs. Mountjoy's eight or ten Days after, and there were moſt of the Company that was at the firſt Meeting, and there all that were preſent did aſſure Mr. Chernock that they kept to their firſt Reſolution, and wou'd abide to what was agreed upon at the former Meeting.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Who were preſent at the ſecond Meeting?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: The Priſoner at the Barr was there at that ſecond Meeting.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What was that ſecond Meeting for, do you ſay?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: It was to give Mr. Chernock aſſurance, that we were agreed to ſtand by the Reſolution taken at the firſt Meeting.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What did Mr. Chernock do afterwards?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: I went away from them; there was Sir William Parkyns, Sir John Freind and Captain Chernock went to the Queens-Head Tavern in Fleetſtreet, and Captain Chernock told me he wou'd go in two or three Days, and I believe did ſo.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: When did you ſee him afterwards?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: When I was a Priſoner upon the account of the Riot in Drurylane; about two or three Days after I came to Newgate he came to ſee me, and ſaid he had been in France; and that King James thank'd us for our kind Offer, but the French King cou'd not ſpare ſo many Men that Year; and he told me he had been with my Lord of Aylesbury, and the reſt of the Gentlemen that had imploy'd him to go over, and had delivered them the ſeveral Meſſages that he was ordered to do from the King.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: Captain Porter, who were preſent at that ſecond Meeting, do you ſay?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: My Lord of Aylesbury, Sir John Freind, Sir William Parkyns, Captain Chernock, Mr. Cook and my ſelf; I cannot tell whether my Lord Montgomery or Mr. Goodman were at that ſecond Meeting or no.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Captain Porter, I wou'd ask you another Queſtion: You were concerned in the Aſſaſſination with thoſe other Perſons that Ingaged in it; Pray what Safety did you propoſe to your ſelves after the Aſſaſſination was over?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: My Lord, I ask'd Sir George Barclay what we ſhou'd do after the Fact was committed: Says he, You need fear nothing, I will go away that night, I have a Ship ready, and the King will be Landed in five or ſix Days afterwards; if you'll but keep ſelves cloſe for ſo many days, all will do well.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: If the Priſoner or the Counſel will ask him any Queſtions, my Lord, they may do it.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Pray Sir, can you recollect what time a day this was that this Debate and Reſolution were had at the Old King's-Head in Leaden-Hallſtreet?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: Truly Sir Bartholomew, I can't tell.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Pray, by what means do you recollect that this was in the Month of May?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: Becauſe Captain Chernock was abſent at the Dog-Tavern Riot, which was the Tenth of June.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Was it not in April?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: No, Sir; to the beſt of my Remembrance it was in May.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: What makes you think it was in May rather than April?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: I have told you Sir, becauſe both Meetings were before the Dog-Tavern Riot, the Tenth of June, and Mr. Chernock was not there at that time; but he told me afterwards he had been in France, and there were eight or ten Days difference between the two Meetings.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, if they have done with him, I wou'd ask him one Queſtion, to ſettle this Matter in point of Time. Capt. Porter, Was the King gone to Flanders when you had theſe Meetings?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: The King was gone, Sir, before the firſt Meeting.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: The King did not go till ſeveral days in May; was Mr. Goodman there?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: He was at the firſt Meeting, but I can't tell whether he was at the ſecond or no.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Darnall.
sp.p: Pray what time was Mr. Goodman there at the firſt Meeting?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: He came up after Dinner at the firſt Meeting.

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: Then call down Mr. Goodman, who came in, and was ſworn.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Mr. Goodman, Pray will you give my Lord and the Jury an Account what you know of an intended Invaſion upon this Kingdom; what were the Circumſtances of it, and who were concerned in it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Goodman.
sp.p: My Lord, About the middle of May laſt, or thereabouts, Captain Porter ſent to me, and told me there was a Meeting of ſome Gentlemen of our acquaintance at the King's-Head in Leaden-Hall-ſtreet; and he deſired me that I wou'd be there, becauſe it was about buſineſs: I told him I did not know whether I cou'd be there at Dinner; but however, I wou'd not fail of coming thither after Dinner; and accordingly I came. When I came into the Houſe, I ſent up my Name to Captain Porter, and he came down and brought me up ſtairs, and there I ſaw my Lord, Montgomery, my Lord of Aylesbury, Sir John Fenwick, Sir William Parkyns, Sir John Freind, Mr. Chernock, and that Gentleman at the Barr, Mr. Cook: When we were there, the Diſcourſe was, That we did think King James's coming was Retarded, and we wou'd do any thing to facilitate his Reſtoration.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: My Lord Chief Juſtice.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: What ſay you, Mr. Cook?

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: My Lord, If your Lordſhip pleaſes, I deſire the Jury may not be talk'd to by any body; and I underſtand there are ſome talking with the Jury.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: Fye upon it, we will lay any body by the Heels that do ſo, they muſt neither be Diſturbed, nor Inſtructed by any body.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: My Lord, I am inform'd there was ſome-body talking to them, and telling them this was the ſame Caſe with Sir John Freind.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: Do you but ſhow us the Man, and we will find another place for him; we will ſend him to the Goal, I'll aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Burleigh.
sp.p: This Gentleman, my Lord, did hear ſuch a Diſcourſe to the Jury (pointing to a Gentleman there) who ſtood up.
My Lord, I cannot poſitively ſwear to the Man, but I did hear ſome Diſcourſe that it was the ſame Evidence as in the former Tryal.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: If you can ſhow us who it was, we will take care to puniſh him: I ſuppoſe he ſtands Corrected; and if we knew who he was, he ſhou'd ſtand Committed.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Goodman, begin again, and tell what paſs'd at that Meeting, becauſe the Jury were interrupted from hearing by People's buzzing about them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Goodman.
sp.p: My Lord, When Captain Porter brought me up into the Room, I told you what Gentlemen I found there; after we were ſet down, there was a Conſultation, that conſidering the French King's Wars Retarded the Affair of ſending back King James, and the means of Reſtoring him to the Crown, it was fit we ſhou'd find out ſome way or method to facilitate his Reſtoration, and it was thought convenient to have a Meſſenger to ſend over to King James with Propoſals for that purpoſe; to this effect, as near as I remember, That if King James cou'd prevail with the French King to furniſh Ten thouſand Men, whereof 8000 to be Foot, 1000 Horſe, and 1000 Dragoons, we wou'd endeavour to meet him at the Head of as many Horſe as we cou'd raiſe, to ſuſtain thoſe Forces at their Landing: This was Debated, in order to come to a Reſolution; and much Difficulty there was how many the Number ſhould be; the Man pitch'd upon to be ſent, was Mr. Chernock; and after ſome Debate, how many Thouſand Horſe could be raiſed: Says Mr. Chernock, Don't let me go over upon a fooliſh Errand, but let me know what I have to ſay exactly: Thereupon it was concluded by all, that Two thouſand Horſe ſhould be the Number we cou'd promiſe, and the King might depend upon them; and if we brought more, ſo much the better; and Sir John Freind ſaid, I believe he has ſo many Friends here, that if he came himſelf, he might be welcome; but that we did not think fit to truſt to; and no body wou'd adviſe any ſuch thing: when the Reſolution of the Thing and the Number was thus fix'd, Mr. Chernock ask'd whether it were with all our Conſents? and that he might aſſure the King, that this was our Reſolution thereupon? we all roſe up, and ſaid to him, Yes, you may, yes, you may, every one particularly; and I remember one thing particularly concerning the Priſoner Mr. Cook, That he kneel'd upon the Chair when he ſaid Yes, you may; and his Elbows were upon the Table: This is all that I know of that Meeting. There was to be another Meeting, as Captain Porter told me; but I had buſineſs in the City: but whatſoever he promiſed on my behalf, as to the Quota of Men, I wou'd be ſure to make it good; and I was not at the ſecond Meeting.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you ſee Mr. Chernock afterwards?

sp.speaker: Mr. Goodman.
sp.p: Yes, I did, when he came back; and he told me the Things was not accepted, for the French King cou'd not ſpare Men, and that he had been with the ſeveral Gentlemen to carry them the Complements that he had in charge from King James, who returned them Thankes for their good Affection; and among the reſt, he did me the Honour to return me Thanks too.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Goodman, let me ask you a Queſtion: When was it that you ſaw Mr. Chernock after this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Goodman.
sp.p: It was in Arundel-ſtreet, at his Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: But I ask you, Sir, when it was? Was it before or after the Tenth of June?

sp.speaker: Mr. Goodman.
sp.p: It was after the Tenth of June, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: How long after, pray.

sp.speaker: Mr. Goodman.
sp.p: I believe it was a Month after the Tenth of June.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Did you ſee him here in England before Mr. Porter was Diſcharged from the Riot, and came out of Newgate?

sp.speaker: Mr. Goodman.
sp.p: I believe I did ſee him before Capt. Porter was Diſcharged, long.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Darnall.
sp.p: Who were the Perſons that were preſent at that Meeting?

sp.speaker: Mr. Goodman.
sp.p: My Lord Montgomery, My Lord of Aylesbury, Sir John Fenwick, Sir John Freind, Sir Wiliam Parkyns, Mr. Chernock, Capt. Porter, and the Priſoner at the Barr, Mr. Cook.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Darnall.
sp.p: Were you at Dinner with them, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Goodman.
sp.p: No, I came in after Dinner.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Darnall.
sp.p: Pray what Houſe was it, do you ſay, this Meeting was at?

sp.speaker: Mr. Goodman.
sp.p: It was at the King's-Head in Leaden-Hall-ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Can you tell what day of the Week it was?

sp.speaker: Mr. Goodman.
sp.p: No, nor the day of the Month.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Was you ever in the Company of theſe Gentlemen at any other time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Goodman.
sp.p: No, this was the only time that I heard of this Conſultation; I was not at the ſecond Meeting.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: If your Lordſhip pleaſes, may I ask Mr. Goodman any Queſtions?

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: Yes, by all means ask him what you will.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Mr. Goodman, You are upon yor Oath: but did you ever hear me ſpeak ten words in your life? was you ever in my Company in any Houſe, before or ſince?

sp.speaker: Mr. Goodman.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; I was in your Company at the Cock in Bowſtreet, where you came in accidentally.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Did you ever hear me talk of the Government, or any thing of that nature?

sp.speaker: Mr. Goodman.
sp.p: What the Diſcourſe was of, I cannot particularly ſay, but I am certain you was there: And as to the Conſultation that I now ſpeak of, I remember very well you gave your Conſent in that manner as I have told the Court.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, we have done at the preſent.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: Then, Brother Darnall, what ſay you for the Priſoner?

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Darnall.
sp.p: May it pleaſe your Lordſhip, and you Gentlemen of the Jury: I am Counſel, in this Caſe, for the Priſoner at the Bar, Mr. Cook, who ſtands Indicted of a very great Offence, no leſs, Gentlemen, than High-Treaſon; and if he be Guilty, his Puniſhment will be as great: But becauſe the Puniſhment and the Offence are both very great, the Law requires exact poſitive Proof, and that by two credible Witneſſes. There have been two indeed that have been produced to you; and if you believe both of them, after what we ſhall offer to you againſt them; and if what they ſwear be true, the Priſoner is Guilty: But if we ſatisfie you that either of them is not to be credited, ſo that you do not believe both of them, he muſt be acquitted.

There is no doubt, Gentlemen, but that here has been a Villanous Horrid Plot; there is no queſtion of it; and it was, as it has been opened, baſely to Aſſaſſinate one of the braveſt Men living; and to make the happieſt People in the World, if they know when they are ſo, the moſt miſerable People upon Earth, by bringing them under French Tyranny and Slavery. Many of the Traytors have been brought to juſt Puniſhment for this Treaſon; nay, they have own'd the Fact at their Death's, ſo that there is no queſtion of the Truth of it; And therefore, Gentlemen, every honeſt Man will endeavour to bring ſuch as are plainly Guilty, of ſuch an abominable Conſpiracy, to juſt Puniſhment; but yet they will be as carefull not to let an innocent Man ſuffer; that, Gentlemen, every honeſt Man will take care of, and eſpecially ſuch as are upon their Oaths: It concerns a Jury highly to be ſatisfied, that he is not Innocent, whom they bring in Guilty; for 'tis better that twenty guilty Men ſhou'd eſcape, than one innocent Man ſuffer.

But, Gentlemen, if my Brief be true, we ſhall give you ſuch an Account of one of theſe Witneſſes; firſt, as to the Man himſelf; that he is not a Man to be credited as a Witneſs; and then beſides that, as to the Evidence he gives in this Caſe; (I ſay, if my Brief be true) it is falſe, and we ſhall prove it ſo; and when you have heard our Evidence, if you are ſatisfied that one of theſe Witneſſes is not to be credited, or that what he ſwears is not true, you are to acquit the Priſoner.

Gentlemen, Here has been one Mr. Goodman produced as a Witneſs, one that never was produced before at the Tryal of any of thoſe that have ſuffered, ſo that the truth of their Guilt does not at all depend upon his Evidence, nor does it give any credit to it. This is this Gentleman's firſt Entry upon this Stage; and yet (if my Brief be true) this is not the firſt bloody or cruel Part that he has Acted; for we have a Record of Conviction againſt him, whereby it will appear to you, that he was Indicted (for Endeavouring to Poiſon two Great Dukes) for giving forty Guinea's to an Italian Emprick, one Amidei, and promiſing Two hundred Pounds more when it was effected, to Poiſon the late Duke of Graſton and the preſent Duke of Northumberland; and we ſhall ſhew you, that he was Convicted of it, and Fined a Thouſand Pound for the Offence; which, conſidering the meanneſs of his Circumſtances at that time, was as much as Twenty thouſand Pounds; for he could as well
have paid Twenty, as One then; and it appears too, that Mr. Goodman (nay, it will not be denied by him himſelf) was in this Horrid Plot; and he that wou'd be concern'd to Poiſon two Dukes in a Family, to which he had ſo many Obligations—

sp.speaker: Mr. Goodman.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire leave to ſpeak to this Matter that the Serjeant mentions.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Darnall.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, let me go on; you may talk anon; I have ſeen the Copy of the Record of Conviction, and have it ready to produce.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Mr. Goodman, be quiet, and ſtay till by and by; you will be defended, no doubt, on it; but in the mean time let them go on, and don't interrupt them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Darnall.
sp.p: I ſay, my Lord, he that wou'd be concern'd in ſo vile an Act, as a Contrivance to take away the Lives of two great Dukes, (who were, in effect, his young Maſtes,) that he ſhou'd go to Poiſon them in a Family to which he had been ſo much obliged; and then, he that wou'd be concerned in ſo Horrid a Plot as this was, to deſtroy his Country, and take away the Life of the King; ſure it will be no difficult thing to think that this Man will not ſtick at the little Priſoner's Life at the Barr, eſpecially when he has ſo great a temptation to it, as to ſave his own Life by it.

But perhaps ſome of you may doubt whether it is to ſave his own Life or no: But I believe there are none of you would give any credit to him, if you thought ſo: Therefore, to ſatisfie you of that Fact, we ſhall produce you Evidence of his own Opinion of that matter, beſides the General known Circumſtances he lay under; As, That he was long in Priſon before he charged the Priſoner with any thing, and the Priſoner was at Liberty, went every day abroad for a Week after Mr. Chernock's Tryal, and never abſconded one Minute, but lived publickly, openly and viſibly to all his Friends, and all Strangers: But beſides, Gentlemen, that Mr. Goodman knew he muſt dye, and juſtly and deſervedly for this Horrid Plot and Treaſon himſelf; and had no other way left to ſave his Life, but to come in thus as an Evidence and an Accuſer, which we think will ſhake his Credit with you.

I ſay, beſides all this, (if my Brief be true,) we ſhall prove that he has ſaid himſelf, That either he muſt Hang Peter Cook, or he muſt be Hang'd himſelf. Thus, Gentlemen, he ſwears to ſave his own Life, by taking away another's.

This, Gentlemen, is as to the Man himſelf, that he is not to be credited. But now further, as to the Evidence that he has given; He tells you that he came into the Tavern in Leaden-Hall-ſtreet, and that there he found ſuch Company; he owns he came in after Dinner; and that the other Gentleman, Mr. Porter, owns too; he ſays there were preſent at this Meeting, my Lord Montgomery, my Lord of Aylesbury, Mr. Cook, and ſeveral other Gentlemen; but (if my Brief be true) we ſhall prove by three Witneſſes, that he was not there till they were gone; and that will make an end of all the pretence of his Evidence.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Nay, then we ſhall never have done.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Darn.
sp.p: I'll aſſure you, Sir, I have the Names of Three Witneſſes in my Brief, to prove that my Lord of Ailesbury, my Lord Montgomery, and Mr. Cook, were gone before he came in, tho' if any, or either of them were gone, it deſtroys his Teſtimony; and if we prove this to you, I wou'd be loath to be one of the Jury that ſhould take away the Priſoner's Life upon this Evidence; no, it he were the vileſt Man alive, and much leſs the Life of the Priſoner at the Bar; for we ſhall prove (if my Brief be true.) he is a Man of Morals, a Man of Virtue, one that has a great Love for his Country; and this we ſhall prove by Evidence undeniable▪ Perſons of Quality in their Country, ſuch as ſerve their Country in Parliament, as their Repreſentatives; we ſhal ſhew it by ſuch Evidence, that there will be no Room to doubt of it: He is a Man without any Stain or Blot upon him, til this Accuſation; he is the eldeſt Son of his Father, and Heir to a great Eſtate; his Father is a great Officer, and a great Getter under this Government; and can it be imagin'd, or believ'd, that ſuch a Man would be guilty of the worſt of Treaſons, to deſtroy the Religion he profeſſes, to over-turn the State, to ruine his own Eſtate, himſelf and his Poſterity, which muſt be the Conſequence of it? Nay, if two good Witneſſes cou'd be produc'd to teſtifie it, and if we had not had ſo much to take off the Credit of Goodman, I cou'd hardly believe it of any Man that was in his right Senſes; he muſt have been a Mad-man if he had done it, one that ſtood ſo well with the preſent Government, and of a Family never tainted with Diſloyalty.

Certainly, Gentlemen, when we make out this to you againſt Mr. Goodman, the Priſoner can be in no Danger of his Life, from Mr. Goodman's Evidence, tho' he is an unfortunate Man to come under ſuch an Accuſation; but I cannot believe that any Jury, upon ſuch a Man's Evidence, will brand an honeſt Family with the fouleſt, vileſt, blackeſt Treaſon that ever was hatch'd; no, Gentlemen, you are Men of Ability and Underſtanding, and that is it we relie upon; we doubt not but that you will conſider the Evidence, and conſider your Oaths, and not let the Priſoner's Blood lie at your Doors; therefore we ſhall go on and call our Witneſſes to make out what I have open'd.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: My Lord, we deſire to call our Witneſſes, and I ſhall reſerve my ſelf to make ſome Obſervations after we have given our Evidence: Mr. Serj. has open'd as much as we can prove, and we will now produce our Evidence; Firſt we will ſhew the Conviction of Goodman: Mr. Burleigh, where is the Conviction?

sp.speaker: Mr. Brul.
sp.p: Here it is, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir. B. Shower.
sp.p: Where had you it, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burleigh,
sp.p: Out of the Treaſury at Weſtminſter?

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Is it a true Copy, did you examine it there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burleigh.
sp.p: Yes, it is a true Copy, I did examine it with the Record.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Then read it, Mr. Tanner.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Read—Michaelmas Term: Triceſimo ſecundo Caroli Secundi.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: Read the Record in Engliſh to the Jury.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p:
(Reads). Be it remember'd, that Sir Robert Sawyer, Knight, Attorney General of our Lord the King that now is, who for the ſame our Lord the King in this part ſueth, came here in the Court of our ſaid Lord the King, before the King himſelf at Weſtminſter, on Thurſday next after three Weeks of St. Michael, the ſame Term; and for the ſame our Lord
the King, brought here into the Court of our ſaid Lord the King, before the ſaid King, then and there, a certain Information againſt Cardell Goodman, late of the Pariſh of St. Martin in the Fields, in the Country of Middleſex, Gentleman, which Information follows in theſe Words. Scilicet, Middleſex ſcilicet, Be it remember'd that Sir Robert Sawyer, Knight, Attorney General of our ſaid Lord the King that now is, who for the ſame our Lord the King, in this behalf ſueth, in his own proper Perſon came here into the Court of our ſaid Lord the King, before the King himſelf at Weſtminſter, on Thurſday next after three Weeks of St. Michael that ſame Term, and for the ſame our Lord the King, gives the Court here to underſtand and be inform'd, That Cardell Goodman, late of the Pariſh of St. Martin in the Fields, in the County of Middleſex, Gentleman, being a Perſon of a wicked Mind, and of an ungodly and deviliſh Diſpoſition, and Converſation and contriving, practiſing, and falſely, maliciouſly and deviliſhly intending Death, and Poiſoning and final Deſtruction unto the Right Nobel Henry, Duke of Grafton, and George, Duke of Northumberland, and that the aforeſaid Cardell Goodman, his moſt wicked, moſt impious, and deviliſh Intentions, Contrivances and Practices aforeſaid, to fulfil, perfect, and bring to effect, the thirtieth Day of September, in the ſix and thirtieth Year of the Reign of our Lord Charles the Second, now King of England, &c. and diverſe other Days, and Times, as well before as after, at the Pariſh of St. Martin in the Fields, in the Country of Middleſex, with Force and Arms, &c. falſely, unlawfully unjuſtly, wickedly, and deviliſhly, by unlawful Ways and Means, did ſolicite, perſwade, and endeavour to procure one Alexander Amydei, to prepare and procure two Flasks of Florence Wine, to be mix'd with deadly Poiſon, for the poiſoning of the aforeſaid Right Noble, Henry, Duke of Grafton, and George, Duke of Northumberland, and his moſt impious, and deviliſh Contrivances, Practices and Intentions aforeſaid, to fulfil, perfect and the more to bring to effect, the aforeſaid Cardell Goodman, the Day and Year aboveſaid, at the Pariſh aforeſaid, in the Country aforeſaid, falſely, unlawfully, unjuſtly, maliciouſly and deviliſhly, did promiſe and agree, to give unto the aforeſaid Alexander Amydei, forty Pieces of Guniea-Gold, of the Value of forty Pound, of lawful Money of England, if he the ſaid Alexander Amydei wou'd prepare, procure and provide two Flasks of Florence Wine, to be mix'd with deadly Poiſon, for the poiſoning of the aforeſaid Right Noble Henry, Duke of Grafton, and George, Duke of Northumberland; and if the aforeſaid Poiſon with the Wine aforeſaid to be mix'd, ſhou'd effect the Death of the aforeſaid Henry, Duke of Grafton, and George, Duke of Northumberland; that then he the ſaid Cardell Goodman, wou'd give unto the ſaid Alexander Amydei, the Summ of one Hundred Pounds, and that beyond Sea he wou'd maintain the ſaid Alexander all the Days of him the ſaid Alexander, to the evil and moſt pernicious Example of all others in the like Caſe offending, and againſt the Peace of our ſaid Lord the King that now is, his Crown and Dignity, &c.—Then here is proceſs pray'd by the Attorney General againſt Mr. Goodman, who comes, and by his Attorney pleads not Guilty, and here is Iſſue joyn'd.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Well, ſee for the Verdict.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: There was a Tryal at Ni • i Prius, and the Jury find that the ſaid Cardell Goodman is Guilty of the Premiſſes in the Information ſpecify'd, as by the Information is ſuppoſed againſt him.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Now read the Judgment.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Thereupon it is conſider'd, that the ſaid Cardell Goodman do pay to the King, the Summ of One Thouſand Pounds, for his Fine, impos'd upon him for the Occaſion a foreſaid, and that the aforeſaid Cardell Goodman be committed to the Marſhalſea of this Court, in Execution for his fine aforeſaid, that he be ſafely kept there, till he pay his Fine aforeſaid; and before that the ſaid Cardell Goodman, is deliver'd out of the Priſon aforeſaid, he ſhall give Security to behave himſelf well, during his Life, and alſo ſhall give Security for the Peace to be kept towards the ſaid Lord the King, and all his People, and particularly towards the Right Noble Henry, Duke of Grafton, and George, Duke of Northumberland.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Darn.
sp.p: So, you hear the Record of the Information, Conviction and Judgment, for a very horrid, abominable Crime.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: But I deſire they may now go on, and read the whole of the Record.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Reads. And afterwards, to wit, on Friday next after eight Days of St. Hilary, in the thirty ſixth, and thirty ſeventh Years of the Reign of our ſaid Lord the King that now is, before our ſaid Lord the King at Weſtminſter came the aforeſaid Sir Robert Sawyer, Knight, Attorney General of the ſaid Lord the King that now is, and acknowledged that the ſaid Cardell Goodman, has ſatisfy'd to our ſaid Lord the King that now is, of the Judgment aforeſaid againſt him, in Form aforeſaid given, therefore the ſaid Cardell Goodman is thereof acquitted, And ſo forth.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Darn.
sp.p: Call Mr. Charles Edwards, William Cock, Chriſtopher Crawford, Marry Crawford, and Mr. Huntley.

div.p: Edwards appear'd upon a Habeas Corpus, directed to the Keeper of Newgate, where he was a Priſoner.

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: Where is the Warrant of his Commitment? what is he committed for?

sp.speaker: Tokefeild.
sp.p: He is committed for ſuſpicion of Treaſon, and treaſonable Practices.

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: Is he not committed for High-Treaſon?

sp.speaker: Tokefeild.
sp.p: No, Sir, he is not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Darn.
sp.p: What Diſcourſe had you with Mr. Goodman, concerning the Priſoner at the Bar, what did you here him ſay?

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: He is not ſworn yet, it ſeems this Gentleman was Dundee's Chaplain in Scotland.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attorn. Gen.
sp.p: If he be not ſworn, he can give no Evidence.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Darn.
sp.p: My Lord, we deſire he may be ſworn.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: Sware him, (which was done).

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Darn.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, will you tell the Court, and the Jury, what you know of any Diſcourſe of Mr. Goodman's, concerning the Priſoner at the Bar.

sp.speaker: Edwards.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire to know, being ignorant of the Law, whether I am brought here by the common courſe of Juſtice or not?

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Darn.
sp.p: Sir, we have ſubpena'd you for the Priſoner at the Bar, to give Evidence of the truth of you Knowledge here upon Oath.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: Would you have us tell you how you came here? We ſuppoſe you came by due Proceſs of Law, as a Witneſs.

sp.speaker: Edwards.
sp.p:
Then, my Lord, I deſire to ſpeak but one Word, that is a ſtrange thing to me to conſider, how Words ſhould be carried away that were privately ſpoken, as if it were to expoſe me to the Reproaches
of all my Friends; it is a thing that I did never expect to hear of again: however, ſeeing I am called here, and obliged upon my Oath to declare what I know, I, by God's Grace, will to the uttermoſt of my power, tell what has paſs'd in this Matter.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: Don't make any Apologies for telling the Truth; you are obliged by your Oath to do it, and the Court expects it from you.

sp.speaker: Edwards.
sp.p: Among other Diſcourſes that paſs'd betwixt Mr. Goodman and me, I ask'd him when Mr. Cook was to be arraigned, and when he was to be tryed; ſays he, He is to be arraigned upon Monday, and he is to be tryed upon Thurſday: I ask'd him whether it was for the Aſſaſſination-Plot, and he told me, no; for what then, ſaid I, as being concerned in ſending Mr. Chernock into France? Who are the Evidences againſt him, ſaid I? ſaid he, Capt. Porter, and my ſelf; ſaid I, I believe two Witneſſes will be found good, or by way of Demonſtration in Law; and I pity the poor Gentleman's Caſe. Says he, He ſwore againſt me; how comes it then, ſaid I, that he is not come off, and has not a Pardon, and would divulge no Body elſe?

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: Who had not a Pardon do you mean?

sp.speaker: Edwards. Mr. Cook.
sp.p: I ask'd how he had not a Pardon; ſays he, he wou'd give an account of no body elſe but me, and that was the Reaſon he had no Pardon; ſaid I to him, who are the Evidences againſt him? ſays he, Capt. Porter, and my ſelf, and after this, ſays he, he, or I, muſt periſh, or he, or I, muſt ſuffer, I believe the word was ſuffer; but, ſays he, 'tis a fooliſh thing to be hang'd; all that's ſaid of a Man that is hang'd, is, that he hang'd hanſomly, or he dy'd bravely, that's all the Diſcourſe that I can remember.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Darn.
sp.p: He ſaid it was a fooliſh thing to be hang'd, and Mr. Goodman, it ſeems, had no mind to be hang'd; and I believe ſo too: but he muſt not hang my Client, to ſave his own life.

sp.speaker: Edwards.
sp.p: Now, by the ſame Oath that I have ſworn, I knew nothing of being brought hither, till my words were carry'd away privately from me, and has been conſulted of, and return'd to me back again; and I was far from ſuborning or carrying away a Diſcourſe privately to make any advantage of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Darn.
sp.p: Now we will call Crawford, and Huntley, and Cock.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attorn. Gen.
sp.p: I deſire that Gentleman that was laſt examin'd may not go away.

sp.speaker: Sir. B. Shower.
sp.p: Set up Mr. Crawford (which was done) pray, Sir, will you recollect your ſelf; do you remember when my Lord of Ailesbury and Capt. Porter din'd at the King's Head.

sp.speaker: Crawford.
sp.p: Yes; it was about a twelve month ago.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Darn.
sp.p: What Company was there?

sp.speaker: Crawford.
sp.p: My Lord of Ailesbury, Sir John Friend, Sir John Fenwick, Sir William Parkyns, Capt. Porter, and two or three more, I did not know their Names.

sp.speaker: Sir. B. Shower.
sp.p: How many were there that din'd there?

sp.speaker: Crawford.
sp.p: I think about Eight in all.

sp.speaker: Sir. B. Shower.
sp.p: Was the Room ſhut while they were there, or did the Servants and Drawers, go up and down commonly?

sp.speaker: Crawford.
sp.p: Yes they did go up and down commonly.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: After Dinner did any body come to them while they were there?

sp.speaker: Crawford.
sp.p: No, not during my Lord of Ailesbury's ſtay, and my Lord Montgomery went away with him?

sp.speaker: Sir. B. Shower.
sp.p: About time did my Lord of Ailesbury go away?

sp.speaker: Crawford.
sp.p: I think it was about four a Clock.

sp.speaker: Sir. B. Shower.
sp.p: How can you tell it?

sp.speaker: Crawford.
sp.p: I did attend upon them the moſt part of the time.

sp.speaker: Sir. B. Shower.
sp.p: Did you ſee him go away?

sp.speaker: Crawford.
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Sh.
sp.p: Was that Gentleman, Mr. Goodman, there, when they went away?

sp.speaker: Crawford.
sp.p: I did not ſee him there, to my Remembrance; no body came in there before they went away, ſaving their own Servants.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Darn.
sp.p: Do you know Mr. Cook, the Priſoner at the Bar, was he one of the Gentlemen that were at your Houſe?

sp.speaker: Crawford.
sp.p: Yes, I did not well remember or recollect, till I ſaw him on Saturday laſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attorn. Gen.
sp.p: Was he one that went away?

sp.speaker: Crawford.
sp.p: I do not remember truly, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Prav how long was it after Dinner that they went away?

sp.speaker: Crawford.
sp.p: I think it was not an Hour.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Was you there all the time, from the time of the Dinner?

sp.speaker: Crawf.
sp.p: No, not all the while I was not in the Room, but going to and fro.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Darn.
sp.p: You ſay Mr. Goodman did not come up till after they were gone?

sp.speaker: Crawford.
sp.p: No, I did not ſee him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attorn. Gen.
sp.p: Did you ſee him at all?

sp.speaker: Crawford.
sp.p: No, I did not ſee him at all.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attorn. Gen.
sp.p: Juſt now it was ſaid he did not come till they were gone, and now it ſeemes he did not ſee him at all.

sp.speaker: Crawford.
sp.p: I do not know that he was there at all.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Tre.
sp.p: But, Brother Darnall, you open'd it, that Mr. Goodman came after my Lord of Ailesbury was gone, and now you will prove it that he came not at all.

sp.speaker: Sir. B. Shower.
sp.p: My Lord, we do not pretend to falſifie his Evidence for any thing more than is material for the Priſoner; we ſay Mr. Goodman was not in the Room where they din'd till thoſe Perſons went away, if in any particular we diſprove him. it is ſufficient for us; if we can ſhew that he was not there till three of thoſe that he had nam'd were gone away, that anſwers our end. We are not concerned if he came at four, five, or ſix a Clock, and diſcours'd with Chernock till twelve a Clock at Night.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray reſerve your Remarks, but only obſerve now what he ſays, that Mr. Goodman came not at all thither, and that is more than you pretended to open.

sp.speaker: Mr. Conyers.
sp.p: How many were there that were there at dinner?

sp.speaker: Crawf.
sp.p: About eight.

sp.speaker: Mr. Conyers.
sp.p: How many do you name that you know?

sp.speaker: Crawf.
sp.p: My Lord of Ailesbury, Sir John Friend, Sir John Fenwick, Sir William Parkyns, and Capt. Porter, there were ſeveral others; two or three more, but I did not know their Names.

sp.speaker: Mr. Conyers.
sp.p: Did you ſee Mr. Goodman come in at any part of the Day afterwards?

sp.speaker: Crawf.
sp.p: I do not know that Mr. Goodman.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cowper.
sp.p: Mr. Crawford, you ſay, that for an hour after Dinner you were ſometimes in the Room and ſometimes out; when you were out of the Room, were you always in the Paſſage up to the Room?

sp.speaker: Crawf.
sp.p: No, I was not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cowper.
sp.p: Cou'd any Man come in or out without your ſeeing?

sp.speaker: Crawf.
sp.p: I ſhould have known him above ſtairs when I came in again.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cowper.
sp.p: Why, you ſay, there were two or three above that you did not know.

sp.speaker: Crawf.
sp.p: I knew them by Sight, if not their Names.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cowper.
sp.p: Were you always in ſight then?

sp.speaker: Crawf.
sp.p: No, Sir, I tell you I was up and down.

sp.speaker: Sir. B. Shower.
sp.p: Was there any body came in before my Lord of Ailesbury went out, that is, any body beſides thoſe that din'd there?

sp.speaker: Crawf.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: My Lord, we are not contending now about a Man's comeing up without his knowledge, but whether any ſuch Man, as Mr. Goodman, came up and ſtaid there, during the Conſultation, and we inſiſt upon it; there was no body there, till my Lord of Ailesbury, my Lord Montgomery, and Mr. Cook were gone, but thoſe that din'd there: now I would ask a Queſtion again of him, was there any body but who din'd there, till my Lord of Ailesbury went away?

sp.speaker: Crawf.
sp.p: No, there was not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Why do you ſay ſo? How do you know that?

sp.speaker: Crawf.
sp.p: I did not ſee any body.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Did you attend upon other Rooms, as well as that, at the ſame time?

sp.speaker: Crawf.
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Then how is it poſſible that he can ſwear that Mr. Goodman was not there?

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Do you remember when my Lord of Alesbury and they went away?

sp.speaker: Crawford.
sp.p: It was about Four a Clock.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Were you there in the Room when they went away?

sp.speaker: Crawf.
sp.p: I went out with my Lord to the Coach.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Did you ſee him come down Stairs, or did you go up Stairs then?

sp.speaker: Crawf.
sp.p: I went up Stairs when the Coach was called.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Was then any body there but ſuch as din'd there?

sp.speaker: Crawf.
sp.p: I did not ſee any body there but thoſe that din'd there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cowper.
sp.p: But, my Lord, he does not know all that din'd there neither.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby. Mr. Crawford,
sp.p: you ſay my Lord of Ailesbury and others went away about Four a Clock; pray how long did the reſt of the Company ſtay there?

sp.speaker: Crawf.
sp.p: I cannot remember. They ſtay'd there pretty late: it is a pretty while ago.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: About what hour did they part?

sp.speaker: Crawf.
sp.p: I cannot remember what time the reſt went away; our Houſe is fuller at Night than at Noon; and I waited upon other Companies. It was pretty late before they went away, that I am ſure.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: But he cannot remember whether it were Five, or Six, or Twelve that they went away, only he can remember the Hour of Four, that my Lord of Ailesbury and they went away.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Rokeby.
sp.p: Was it Light, or was it Dark when they went away?

sp.speaker: Crawford.
sp.p: It was Dark.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: Did you attend the Company after my Lord of Aliesbury was gone?

sp.speaker: Crawford.
sp.p: I went up and down into that Company as I did into others.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: Was you there ſeveral times after my Lord of Ailesbury was gone?

sp.speaker: Crawf.
sp.p: Yes, I was there once or twice after my Lord of Ailesbury was gone, I am ſure.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: And did you never ſee Mr. Goodman there?

sp.speaker: Crawf.
sp.p: No, I never ſaw Mr. Goodman in my Life, before I ſaw him on Saturday laſt.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Which is Mr. Huntley?

sp.speaker: Huntley.
sp.p: Here I am, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Pray recollect your ſelf, and tell my Lord and the Jury what you remember of any Company that were with Mr. Porter, at the King's-Head, and who din'd there.

sp.speaker: Huntley.
sp.p: My Lord of Ailesbury, my Lord Montgomery, Sir John Fenwick, Sir William Parkyns, Sir John Friend, Mr. Porter and Mr. Chernock.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: That was the Company, you ſay, that din'd there: Did Mr. Goodman dine there?

sp.speaker: Huntley.
sp.p: No, Mr. Goodman did not dine there.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, recollect your ſelf, when did any of this Company part, or go away?

sp.speaker: Huntley.
sp.p: My Lord of Ailesbury, and my Lord Montgomery went away about four a Clock.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Sir, how do you know that?

sp.speaker: Huntley.
sp.p: I went down Stairs after them, I was above Stairs when they parted from the reſt of the Company.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Darn.
sp.p: Pray mind, Sir, was Mr. Goodman there at that Time before they went away?

sp.speaker: Huntley.
sp.p: No, he was not.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Are you ſure of that, upon the Oath you have taken?

sp.speaker: Huntley.
sp.p: Yes, I take it upon my Oath, he was not there.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Did you attend them at Dinner?

sp.speaker: Huntley.
sp.p: Yes, I did attend them at Dinner.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Did you attend them all the while they were there?

sp.speaker: Huntley.
sp.p: I was call'd frequently, and was in and out of the Room very much after Dinner.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Do you think if a freſh Man had come in after Dinner, you ſhould not have known him?

sp.speaker: Huntley.
sp.p: Yes, I ſhould have known him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, Friend, let me ask you one Queſtion. Was Mr. Goodman there at all that Day?

sp.speaker: Huntley.
sp.p: That I don't know, I did not ſee him at all.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Did you attend upon any other Rooms that Day?

sp.speaker: Huntley.
sp.p: No, I attended only upon that Company.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Were you in the Room all the time?

sp.speaker: Huntley.
sp.p: No, I went up and down.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: What time did the laſt of the Company go away?

sp.speaker: Huntley.
sp.p: It was about Darkiſh, it was pretty Late to the beſt of my remembrance.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, did any body come to thoſe Gentlemen after Dinner?

sp.speaker: Huntley.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: did you ever ſee Goodman before now?

sp.speaker: Huntley.
sp.p: Never in my Life, to my Knowledge.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Rokeby.
sp.p: Did all the Company, but my Lord of Ailesbury, and my Lord Montgomery, ſtay till it was Duskiſh?

sp.speaker: Huntley.
sp.p: That I don't know.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Rokeby.
sp.p: Did you know all the Company that was that Day at Dinner?

sp.speaker: Huntley.
sp.p: I knew all but one.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Rokeby.
sp.p: And who was that?

sp.speaker: Huntley.
sp.p: That was Mr. Chernock.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Rokeby.
sp.p: And yet you can't tell whether there was any body elſe that you did not know, how then can you tell that Goodman was not there?

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: He did not know him at that time, but he might remember him afterwards.

sp.speaker: Mr. Conyers.
sp.p: Did not the ſame Company uſe to meet at other Times, at your Houſe?

sp.speaker: Huntl.
sp.p: Not to my Remembrance.

sp.speaker: Mr. Con.
sp.p: How then came you, if they never had us'd to meet there, to know all theſe People's Names?

sp.speaker: Huntley,
sp.p: I have ſeen Sir John Friend there, and Sir William Parkyns.

sp.speaker: Mr. Con.
sp.p: Was Sir John Friend there, or no?

sp.speaker: Huntl.
sp.p: Yes, he was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Con.
sp.p: My Lord, he was the only Man that was not nam'd before, you did not name Sir John Friend before, as I heard, but pray, did you ever ſee Mr. Chernock there, but at that time?

sp.speaker: Huntley.
sp.p: No, I did not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Con.
sp.p: How came you to know it was Mr. Chernock?

sp.speaker: Huntl.
sp.p: I knew very few of them before that time, and I ask'd their Servants the Names of all thoſe Perſons that were there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Con.
sp.p: Did you know Mr. Porter, pray?

sp.speaker: Huntl.
sp.p: Not before that Time, I did ſee Mr. Porter, and I knew him again when I ſaw him, his Black told me his Name that Day.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: You, Huntley, I would ask you one Queſtion more, was the Door ſhut, or no?

sp.speaker: Huntl.
sp.p: No, it was not.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Did the Servants go up and down as they us'd to do?

sp.speaker: Huntl.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Sir Bartholomew would make it that there was no Conſultation at all.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: They wer very mad Folks if they wou'd conſult at that Rate with the Door open. Pray call Mr. William Cock, (who was ſworn).

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Sir John Friend has own'd it, that's dead.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Sir John Friend's Confeſſion is nothing to the Priſoner.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Mr. Serj. Darnall did open, that the Confeſſion of thoſe that dy'd, was an undeniable Proof of the Conſpiracy; but go on with your Evidence.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sarj. Darn.
sp.p: Pray Mr. Cock, will you recollect your ſelf, about the Time when Cap. Porter, and ſome other Gentlemen din'd at your Houſe.

sp.speaker: W. Cock.
sp.p: Yes, very well.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Darn.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, can you tell who din'd there at that time?

sp.speaker: W. Cock.
sp.p: There were my Lord of Ailesbury, my Lord Montgomery, Sir William Parkyns, Sir John Fenwick, Sir John Friend, Mr. Chernock, Cap. Porter and Mr. Cook.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Rokeby.
sp.p: Was that all the Company?

sp.speaker: W. Cock.
sp.p: Yes, it was.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Rokeby.
sp.p: One of them ſaid there were Eight.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: and he has nam'd Eight, Brother.

sp.speaker: M. Serj. Darn.
sp.p: Can you remember when any of the Company went away, and who went away firſt?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: My Lord of Aylesbury and my Lord Montgomery went away in a Hackney Coach; and their Servants were frequently in the Room, and waited afterwards in another Room, after that they had waited at Table at Dinner; and tho' the Door was ſhut, as it uſed to be when any Company is there, yet no body was forbid to come there at all.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Do you remember when Mr. Goodman came there?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I never ſaw Mr. Goodman in my life before to day.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Darnall.
sp.p: Did any body come to this Company before my Lord of Aylesbury went away that did not Dine there?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I did not ſee any body there at all; and my Lord of Aylesbury was about buying a Hogſhead of White-wine, but we could not agree about the Price: And when my Lord of Aylesbury went away, I went down with my Lord, and waited upon him to the Coach; and I told my Lord, I hoped he would buy the Wine ſtill. But he anſwered, He could not tell whether he ſhould or no.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Darnall.
sp.p: Who elſe went with my Lord of Aylesbury?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: My Lord Montgomery. I don't remember any body elſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Rokeby.
sp.p: Did all the reſt of the Company go away at once?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Truly, my Lord, I can't ſay they did.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Rokeby.
sp.p: By what time did the reſt go away?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I believe it might be Eight or Nine a Clock.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Darnall.
sp.p: You ſaw my Lord of Aylesbury when he parted: Was Mr. Goodman there then?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I did not ſee him.

sp.speaker: Mr. B. Powis.
sp.p: Did Mr. Cook ſtay till the laſt?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: That I can't tell truly.

sp.speaker: Mr. B. Powis.
sp.p: I find they all Swear to Four a Clock of my Lord Aylesbury's going, and go no further.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, let me ask you a Queſtion or two: Did you ever ſee Mr. Goodman before now?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: No, I do not remember I did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: When you went into the Room after Dinner, did you look about the Room to ſee whether there were any new Company?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I did look about the Room ſeveral times, and ſo did my Servants, to ſee if there were any thing wanting.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Can you take it upon your Oath, that he was not there whilſt my Lord of Aylesbury ſtaid?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I do, and can take it upon my Oath, he was not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Then if you can, pray diſtinguiſh the time when he came in.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I do not remember that ever I ſaw him in my Life before to day.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Why are you not as poſitive that he was not there at all, as that he was not there before my Lord of Aylesbury went away?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: He might come in, and I not ſee him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Might he not as well come in before they went away, as after to come in and you not ſee him?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: No, I do not think he cou'd.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Why do you think ſo?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Becauſe the Servants were all about, and they did not go to Dinner till two a Clock; and I believe thoſe Gentlemen that I named came in a quarter of an Hour's time to Dinner.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: We do not ſay he came there before Dinner; but cou'd he not come in after Dinner, before my Lord of Aylesbury and my Lord Montgomery went away, without your ſeeing him?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Then heark ye, Sir, I wou'd ask you one Queſtion, Did you ſee him, upon your Oath, or not?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: No, I did not.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Might not Mr. Goodman come in to them without your ſeeing him?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: It is poſſible, but I don't think it was ſo.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Rokeby.
sp.p: How then can you be poſitive that he was not there till my Lord of Aylesbury went?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: You ſay you may be poſitive he was not there before my Lord of Aylesbury went: Can you be as poſitive now, that he was not there before Mr. Cook went?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I do not know when Mr. Cook went.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: How can you be then poſitive he was not there before my Lord of Aylesbury went?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: There were no more than what Dined there when my Lord of Aylesbury went away.

sp.speaker: Mr. Conyers.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, let me ask you a Queſtion: Were you in the Room at any time after Dinner?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Yes, I was, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Conyers.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, how many times after Dinner were you there?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I believe half a dozen times.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: And yet you do confeſs that Mr. Goodman might come in after Dinner before my Lord of Aylesbury went, and you not ſee him?

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Ay, but he could not ſtay there without his ſeeing him, if he was ſo often in the Room; you don't take Mr. Cock's Evidence right.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: You named Eight Perſons that Dined at your Houſe; Did you know them all perſonally before that day?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, the moſt of them at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did they uſe to meet at your Houſe?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Commonly Sir John Friend did once a Week. Mr. Chernock I knew when I was a Drawer, and ſo I did Sir William Parkyns: The reſt knew by hearing their Names.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you know them before that Day Sir, I ask you?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I had ſeen Captain Porter ſeveral times before that Day, but I cannot ſay at my own Houſe.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Do you remember the Treaty about the Hogſhead of Whitewine?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, very well.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Were you by when my Lord of Aylesbury went away, and ſpoke with him about it?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Yes, I was; and told him, I hoped he would buy the Wine ſtill.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Can you be poſitive that any body was there before my Lord of Aylesbury went away, that cou'd ſtay there any time, and did not Dine there?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I believe not, Sir; for I came in half a dozen times after Dinner, and I believe if I had heard Mr. Goodman's Name, or ſeen him there, I ſhou'd have remembred it; but I did not ſee any body but thoſe that Dined there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cowper.
sp.p: Where was you when my Lord of Aylesbury went away? Where did you meet him going away?

sp.speaker: Cock.
